planting.notes: Needs warm soil (60°F+). Start indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost.

care.watering: Water deeply at the base, 1-2 inches per week. Avoid wetting foliage.
care.watering_frequency: Every 2-3 days, daily in hot weather
care.fertilizing: Feed every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer once fruiting begins.
care.pruning: Remove suckers for indeterminate varieties. Prune lower leaves touching soil.
care.pests: Watch for hornworms, aphids, and blight. Remove affected leaves promptly.
care.harvesting: Harvest when fully colored but still firm. Can ripen green tomatoes indoors.
tips: Stake or cage plants early
Mulch to prevent soil splash
Water consistently to prevent blossom end rot
Plant deeply - roots grow from buried stem

planting.notes: Very frost sensitive. Can direct sow after soil warms to 70°F.

care.watering: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. About 1 inch per week.
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Apply diluted liquid fertilizer monthly.
care.pruning: Pinch off flower buds to extend harvest. Cut stems above leaf pairs.
care.pests: Susceptible to aphids, slugs, and Japanese beetles.
care.harvesting: Harvest leaves regularly from the top to encourage bushy growth.
tips: Pinch flowers immediately to prevent bolting
Harvest in morning for best flavor
Never refrigerate fresh basil
Plant near tomatoes for mutual benefit

planting.notes: Direct sow only - doesn't transplant well. Keep soil moist for germination.

care.watering: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during germination. 1 inch per week.
care.watering_frequency: Every 2-3 days, keep surface moist until sprouted
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Low nitrogen - too much causes forked roots. Add compost before planting.
care.pruning: Thin seedlings to proper spacing when 2 inches tall.
care.pests: Carrot rust fly, wireworms. Use row covers to prevent flies.
care.harvesting: Pull when shoulders are 1/2 to 3/4 inch diameter. Loosen soil first.
tips: Mix seeds with sand for even sowing
Keep soil loose and rock-free for straight roots
Mulch to keep soil cool and moist
Fall carrots are sweetest after frost

planting.notes: Start very early indoors (10-12 weeks). Can also plant sets 4 weeks before last frost.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Stop watering when tops start to fall over.
care.fertilizing: Feed with nitrogen-rich fertilizer every 2-3 weeks until bulbing.
care.pruning: None needed. Don't cut green tops - they feed the bulb.
care.pests: Onion maggots, thrips. Rotate crops and use row covers.
care.harvesting: Harvest when 50% of tops have fallen. Cure in dry, shaded area for 2 weeks.
tips: Choose correct day-length variety for your latitude
Mulch to conserve moisture
Bend tops over gently to speed maturity
Store only fully cured onions

planting.notes: Cool season crop. Bolts in heat. Plant every 2 weeks for continuous harvest.

care.watering: Keep consistently moist. About 1-2 inches per week. Shallow roots dry quickly.
care.watering_frequency: Daily in hot weather, every 2 days normally
care.sunlight: Partial shade in summer, full sun in spring/fall (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Side-dress with compost or diluted fertilizer.
care.pruning: Cut outer leaves for continuous harvest (cut-and-come-again).
care.pests: Aphids, slugs, rabbits. Use row covers and copper tape for slugs.
care.harvesting: Harvest in morning when leaves are crisp. Cut or pick outer leaves first.
tips: Provide afternoon shade in summer
Bolt-resistant varieties for warm weather
Soak seeds in cold water before summer sowing
Mulch to keep roots cool

planting.notes: Start indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost. Needs warm soil (65°F+).

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Consistent moisture prevents blossom end rot.
care.fertilizing: Feed every 2-3 weeks once flowering. Use low-nitrogen fertilizer.
care.pruning: Pinch first flowers to encourage stronger plants. Remove suckers optionally.
care.pests: Aphids, hornworms, pepper maggots. Check undersides of leaves.
care.harvesting: Cut peppers with scissors. Green peppers ripen to red/yellow if left longer.
tips: Hot peppers need more heat and stress for spiciness
Support heavy plants with stakes
Mulch to keep roots warm
Harvest regularly to encourage production

planting.notes: Direct sow after last frost. Soil should be 60°F+. Don't start indoors.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Water at base to prevent disease. More during flowering.
care.fertilizing: None needed - beans fix nitrogen. Too much causes leafy growth, few beans.
care.pruning: None needed for bush beans.
care.pests: Mexican bean beetles, aphids. Pick beetles by hand. Rotate crops.
care.harvesting: Pick when pods snap cleanly. Harvest every 2-3 days for continuous production.
tips: Don't work in wet bean plants (spreads disease)
Inoculate seeds with rhizobia for better yields
Plant in blocks for better pollination
Leave roots in soil - they add nitrogen

planting.notes: Direct sow after last frost. Needs trellis or support.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Critical during flowering and pod development.
care.fertilizing: Beans fix nitrogen - no fertilizer needed.
care.pruning: Pinch growing tips when vines reach top of support.
care.pests: Mexican bean beetles, aphids, spider mites.
care.harvesting: Harvest every 2-3 days. Pods toughen if left too long.
tips: Install trellis before planting
Train vines up support initially
Produce longer than bush beans
Great for small spaces - grow up, not out

planting.notes: Plant as early as soil can be worked. Cool season crop - stops producing in heat.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Consistent moisture during flowering is critical.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: No nitrogen needed - peas fix their own. Add phosphorus for flowers.
care.pruning: Pinch tips to encourage branching.
care.pests: Aphids, powdery mildew. Good air circulation helps prevent disease.
care.harvesting: Pick daily when ready. Regular picking encourages more production.
tips: Soak seeds overnight before planting
Provide support even for 'dwarf' varieties
Harvest snow peas when flat, snap peas when plump
Pull plants when production stops - compost or till under

planting.notes: Can start indoors 3-4 weeks early for head start. Needs warm soil (70°F+).

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Consistent moisture prevents bitter fruit.
care.watering_frequency: Daily in hot weather, every 2 days normally
care.fertilizing: Feed every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer once vines start running.
care.pruning: Trim lateral vines to focus energy on main vine.
care.pests: Cucumber beetles, powdery mildew. Use row covers until flowering.
care.harvesting: Pick cucumbers when 6-8 inches. Don't let them turn yellow.
tips: Grow on trellis for straight fruit and disease prevention
Pick daily - overripe cukes stop production
Bitter taste means water stress
Plant dill nearby to attract beneficial wasps

planting.notes: Summer squash. Can start indoors but direct sow is fine.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Water at base to prevent powdery mildew.
care.fertilizing: Heavy feeder. Side-dress with compost monthly or use balanced fertilizer.
care.pruning: Remove dead leaves. Trim some leaves to improve air circulation.
care.pests: Squash bugs, vine borers, powdery mildew. Check daily for eggs.
care.harvesting: Harvest summer squash young and tender (6-8 inches).
tips: Hand pollinate in morning if bees are scarce
Place cardboard under fruit to prevent rot
One plant produces 6-10 lbs
Check under leaves daily for squash bug eggs

planting.notes: Very productive. Plant just 2-3 for a family.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week at base of plant.
care.fertilizing: Heavy feeder. Apply compost or fertilizer every 3-4 weeks.
care.pruning: Remove older outer leaves to improve air flow.
care.pests: Squash vine borer, squash bugs, powdery mildew.
care.harvesting: Pick at 6-8 inches for best flavor. Check daily - they grow fast!
tips: Harvest small for best taste
Hand-pollinate for guaranteed fruit
One plant can produce 6-10 lbs per week
Edible flowers can be stuffed and fried

planting.notes: Plant in blocks (not rows) for pollination. Needs warm soil (65°F+).

care.watering: 1.5-2 inches per week. Critical during tasseling and ear development.
care.fertilizing: Heavy nitrogen feeder. Side-dress with nitrogen when knee-high and again at tasseling.
care.pruning: Remove suckers if desired, but not necessary.
care.pests: Corn earworm, raccoons, birds. Apply oil to silk tips for earworms.
care.harvesting: Ready when silk is brown and kernels squirt milky juice when pressed.
tips: Plant in blocks of at least 4x4 for pollination
Three Sisters: plant with beans and squash
Sugar converts to starch after picking - eat immediately
Successive plantings extend harvest

planting.notes: Plant seed potatoes 2-4 weeks before last frost. Can handle light frost.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Keep soil consistently moist, especially during tuber formation.
care.fertilizing: Low nitrogen - too much causes leafy growth. Use balanced fertilizer at planting.
care.pruning: Hill soil around stems as they grow to increase yield.
care.pests: Colorado potato beetle, late blight. Rotate crops and remove beetles by hand.
care.harvesting: New potatoes: harvest when flowering. Storage potatoes: wait 2 weeks after tops die.
tips: Cut seed potatoes to pieces with 2-3 eyes each
Hill soil 6 inches up stems twice
Green potatoes are toxic - keep covered with soil
Cure storage potatoes in dark for 2 weeks

planting.notes: Cool season crop. Start indoors for spring crop, direct sow for fall.

care.watering: 1-1.5 inches per week. Consistent moisture prevents cracking.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Heavy nitrogen feeder. Side-dress with nitrogen-rich fertilizer every 3 weeks.
care.pruning: Remove outer damaged leaves as needed.
care.pests: Cabbage worms, cabbage loopers, aphids. Use row covers and BT spray.
care.harvesting: Harvest when heads are firm and solid. Cut at base, leaving wrapper leaves.
tips: Plant flowers nearby to attract beneficial wasps
Fall crop is often sweeter
Cover with row covers from day one
Twist head slightly to slow growth if splitting threatens

planting.notes: Cool season crop. Fall planting often better - fewer pests, sweeter after frost.

care.watering: 1-1.5 inches per week. Consistent moisture is key for good heads.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Heavy feeder. Side-dress with nitrogen fertilizer when heads start forming.
care.pruning: None needed. Remove yellowing leaves.
care.pests: Cabbage worms, aphids, flea beetles. Use row covers and BT.
care.harvesting: Cut main head when florets are tight. Side shoots continue producing.
tips: Harvest before flowers open (yellow shows)
Side shoots produce for weeks after main head
Fall broccoli sweetens after light frost
Morning harvest keeps heads fresher

planting.notes: Finicky - needs consistent temps 60-70°F. Fall crop often more successful.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Very sensitive to irregular watering.
care.fertilizing: Heavy feeder. Fertilize every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer.
care.pruning: Blanch white varieties by tying leaves over head when 2-3 inches.
care.pests: Same as cabbage - cabbage worms, aphids. Use row covers.
care.harvesting: Harvest when heads are 6-8 inches and still compact.
tips: Most difficult brassica to grow
Blanching keeps heads white
Fall planting is more forgiving
Don't let plants get stressed - they won't recover

planting.notes: Very cold hardy - sweetens after frost. Can overwinter in zones 7+.

care.watering: 1-1.5 inches per week. Mulch to retain moisture.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Moderate feeder. Side-dress with compost or balanced fertilizer monthly.
care.pruning: Harvest outer leaves first. Remove yellowing leaves.
care.pests: Cabbage worms, aphids. Less pest pressure than other brassicas.
care.harvesting: Pick outer leaves when 8-10 inches. Plants keep producing all season.
tips: Sweetest after frost
Can harvest through winter with protection
Baby kale more tender for salads
Massage raw kale to soften for salads

planting.notes: Cool season crop. Bolts quickly in heat. Plant early spring and fall.

care.watering: 1-1.5 inches per week. Consistent moisture prevents bolting.
care.sunlight: Partial shade (3-4 hours) in summer, full sun spring/fall
care.fertilizing: Light nitrogen fertilizer every 2-3 weeks.
care.pruning: Harvest outer leaves for continuous production.
care.pests: Leaf miners, aphids, downy mildew. Use row covers.
care.harvesting: Cut outer leaves at 4-6 inches. Or cut whole plant at base.
tips: Plant in shade of taller crops in summer
Bolt-resistant varieties for late spring
Fall spinach overwinters in many zones
Soak seeds 24 hours for better germination

planting.notes: Each 'seed' is a cluster - thin to one plant. Greens edible too.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Even moisture prevents woody roots.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Low nitrogen. Add boron if roots have black spots inside.
care.pruning: Thin seedlings to 3-4 inches apart. Eat thinnings!
care.pests: Leaf miners, cercospora leaf spot. Rotate crops.
care.harvesting: Harvest roots at 1-3 inches diameter. Greens anytime.
tips: Soak seeds overnight for faster germination
Each seed cluster produces multiple plants - thin!
Fall beets are sweetest
Store in sand in cool root cellar

planting.notes: Very fast! Great for interplanting. Gets woody/hot in summer heat.

care.watering: Keep soil consistently moist. About 1 inch per week.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: None needed for quick-growing radishes.
care.pruning: Thin to 1 inch apart when seedlings appear.
care.pests: Flea beetles, root maggots. Use row covers.
care.harvesting: Pull when roots are 1 inch diameter. Don't leave too long.
tips: Plant every week for continuous harvest
Great for marking slow-germinating seeds
Winter radishes need 60+ days
Over-mature radishes become pithy and hot

planting.notes: Best as fall crop - sweetens after frost. Both roots and greens edible.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Consistent moisture for best roots.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Low nitrogen - too much causes leafy growth, poor roots.
care.pruning: Thin to 4 inches apart.
care.pests: Flea beetles, root maggots, aphids.
care.harvesting: Harvest roots at 2-3 inches. Greens anytime they're big enough.
tips: Fall turnips are sweeter than spring
Greens are nutritious - don't discard!
Store in root cellar or leave in ground with mulch
Harvest before hard freeze

planting.notes: Best planted in fall for summer harvest. Plant individual cloves. Needs cold period.

care.watering: 1 inch per week during active growth. Stop watering 2 weeks before harvest.
care.fertilizing: Feed with nitrogen in early spring when growth resumes.
care.pruning: Cut scapes (flower stalks) on hardneck varieties for bigger bulbs.
care.pests: Few pests. Garlic repels many insects naturally.
care.harvesting: Harvest when lower 3-4 leaves are brown. Cure for 2-3 weeks.
tips: Plant largest cloves for biggest bulbs
Hardneck varieties better for cold climates
Scapes are edible and delicious
Save biggest bulbs for next year's planting

planting.notes: Very long season. Start very early indoors. Mound soil for white stems.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Keep consistently moist.
care.fertilizing: Heavy nitrogen feeder. Fertilize every 3 weeks.
care.pruning: Trim tops to 6 inches when transplanting.
care.pests: Onion thrips, leek moth. Use row covers.
care.harvesting: Harvest anytime after pencil thickness. Cold hardy - leave in ground into winter.
tips: Hill soil around stems for longer white portion
Plant in trench and fill as they grow
Much milder than onions
Can overwinter in ground with mulch

planting.notes: Perennial. Can divide established clumps. Flowers are edible.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Drought tolerant once established.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Top-dress with compost in spring.
care.pruning: Cut back to 2 inches a few times per season to encourage fresh growth.
care.pests: Very few. Chives repel many pests.
care.harvesting: Snip leaves 2 inches above ground. Use scissors.
tips: Perennial - comes back every year
Divide clumps every 3-4 years
Flowers attract beneficial insects
Great for pest control around roses and fruit trees

planting.notes: Perennial - plant crowns in early spring. Don't harvest first 2 years. Produces 15-20 years.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Deep watering encourages deep roots.
care.fertilizing: Feed in spring before spears emerge and after harvest ends.
care.pruning: Let ferns grow all summer. Cut back dead ferns in late fall or early spring.
care.pests: Asparagus beetle. Hand-pick or use neem.
care.harvesting: Harvest spears at 7-9 inches for 6-8 weeks. Stop when spears thin out.
tips: Don't harvest first 2 years - let plants establish
Perennial bed produces 15-20+ years
Male plants more productive
Add compost each spring

planting.notes: Long season, needs consistent moisture. Start very early - slow to germinate.

care.watering: 2+ inches per week. Never let soil dry out!
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (5-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Heavy feeder. Side-dress every 2 weeks with nitrogen.
care.pruning: Blanch stalks by mounding soil or wrapping with paper.
care.pests: Carrot rust fly, aphids, early blight.
care.harvesting: Cut outer stalks as needed, or harvest whole plant.
tips: Most demanding vegetable - needs constant moisture
Seeds need light to germinate
Can overwinter in mild climates
Self-blanching varieties easier

planting.notes: Needs heat - wait until soil is 70°F+. Start indoors 8-10 weeks early.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Consistent watering prevents bitter fruit.
care.fertilizing: Feed every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer during fruiting.
care.pruning: Stake plants and remove some suckers for larger fruit.
care.pests: Flea beetles, Colorado potato beetle, aphids.
care.harvesting: Harvest when skin is glossy. Dull skin = overripe and seedy.
tips: Needs warmth - use black plastic mulch
Pick before skin turns dull
Smaller fruits are less bitter
Japanese varieties more productive in short seasons

planting.notes: Needs hot weather. Soak seeds overnight before planting.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Drought tolerant but produces better with consistent moisture.
care.fertilizing: Side-dress with compost monthly or use balanced fertilizer.
care.pruning: Remove lower leaves as plant grows. Cut spent stalks for side shoots.
care.pests: Few pests. Aphids, stinkbugs occasionally.
care.harvesting: Pick pods at 2-4 inches every 2 days. Gets tough if left.
tips: Soaking seeds speeds germination
Wear gloves - leaves can irritate skin
Harvest every 2 days - pods toughen quickly
Productive until first frost

planting.notes: Plant slips after soil is 65°F+. Needs long, warm growing season.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. More during root development, less in final month.
care.fertilizing: Low nitrogen - too much causes vines, not roots. Add potassium.
care.pruning: Lift vines occasionally to prevent rooting at nodes.
care.pests: Sweet potato weevil, deer, voles.
care.harvesting: Harvest before frost. Cure at 85°F and high humidity for 10 days.
tips: Make own slips from grocery store sweet potato
Curing is essential for sweetness and storage
Don't refrigerate - kills flavor
Vines are edible too

planting.notes: Count back from desired harvest (Oct) for planting date.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Avoid wetting leaves - causes disease.
care.fertilizing: Heavy feeder. Side-dress with nitrogen when vines start running.
care.pruning: Pinch vine tips after fruit set for earlier maturity.
care.pests: Squash bugs, vine borers, powdery mildew.
care.harvesting: Harvest when rind is hard and stem begins to dry. Leave 4-inch stem.
tips: Place cardboard under fruits to prevent rot
Limit to 2-3 fruits per vine for larger pumpkins
Cure in sun for 10 days before storage
Count back 100 days from Halloween to plant

planting.notes: Start indoors in short season areas (zones 3-5). Needs warm soil (70°F+).

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Reduce watering as fruit ripens for sweeter melons.
care.fertilizing: Feed every 2-3 weeks until fruit set.
care.pruning: Pinch off flowers after 3-4 fruits set per vine.
care.pests: Cucumber beetles, aphids, powdery mildew.
care.harvesting: Cantaloupe 'slips' from vine when ripe. Honeydew stays attached.
tips: Use black plastic mulch to warm soil
Support melons on trellises with slings
Reduce watering 1 week before harvest for sweetness
Cantaloupe ready when stem 'slips' from fruit

planting.notes: Needs long warm season. Start indoors in zones 5 and colder.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Reduce as fruit ripens.
care.fertilizing: Side-dress with balanced fertilizer when vines start running.
care.pruning: Can pinch growing tips after fruit set.
care.pests: Same as melons - cucumber beetles, aphids.
care.harvesting: Thump for hollow sound. Spot touching ground turns from white to yellow.
tips: Ground spot turns yellow when ripe
Thump should sound hollow
Tendril nearest fruit turns brown when ripe
Need lots of space - plan 20+ sq ft per plant

planting.notes: Slow to germinate (2-4 weeks). Soak seeds overnight. Biennial.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Keep soil consistently moist.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Compost at planting is sufficient.
care.pruning: Cut outer stems at base to encourage new growth.
care.pests: Swallowtail caterpillars (plant extra to share!), aphids.
care.harvesting: Cut outer stems at base. Plant continues producing all season.
tips: Soak seeds in warm water overnight for faster germination
Biennial - produces seed second year
Flat-leaf has more flavor
Attracts beneficial swallowtail butterflies

planting.notes: Bolts quickly in heat. Plant every 2-3 weeks for continuous harvest.

care.watering: Keep evenly moist. About 1 inch per week.
care.sunlight: Partial shade in summer (4 hours), full sun spring/fall
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Compost at planting is enough.
care.pruning: Harvest frequently to delay bolting.
care.pests: Aphids, leafhoppers. Very few pest problems.
care.harvesting: Snip leaves as needed. When it bolts, harvest coriander seeds.
tips: Bolts very fast in heat - succession plant
Slow-bolt varieties last longer
Seeds (coriander) also valuable - let some bolt
Fall planting most successful

planting.notes: Direct sow - doesn't transplant well. Self-seeds readily.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Drought tolerant once established.
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. No fertilizer needed.
care.pruning: Harvest leaves regularly. Let some flowers set seed.
care.pests: Swallowtail caterpillars (share with them!), aphids.
care.harvesting: Snip leaves anytime. Harvest seed heads when brown.
tips: Self-seeds readily - let some flower
Tall varieties may need staking
Attracts beneficial insects
Essential for pickles - plant near cucumbers

planting.notes: Perennial. Can also propagate from cuttings.

care.watering: Once established, only water during drought. 1/2 inch per week.
care.fertilizing: Very light feeder. Over-fertilizing reduces flavor.
care.pruning: Cut back to 1/3 after flowering. Regular harvesting shapes plant.
care.pests: Very few. Occasionally aphids or spider mites.
care.harvesting: Harvest before flowering for best flavor. Cut stems above leaf nodes.
tips: Perennial - comes back each year
Greek oregano has best flavor
Cut back after flowering to promote new growth
Dries very well

planting.notes: Perennial. Slow from seed - easier to buy starts.

care.watering: Drought tolerant. Water only when soil is dry. 1/2 inch weekly max.
care.watering_frequency: Every 5-7 days, let soil dry between
care.fertilizing: Very light feeder. Too much fertilizer reduces flavor.
care.pruning: Trim after flowering. Cut back woody growth in spring.
care.pests: Very few. Root rot if overwatered.
care.harvesting: Snip sprigs as needed. Best just before flowering.
tips: Perennial groundcover
Many varieties - try lemon thyme
Perfect for rock gardens
Don't overwater - Mediterranean plant

planting.notes: Perennial zones 8+. Overwinter indoors in colder zones.

care.watering: Very drought tolerant. Water deeply but infrequently. 1/2 inch weekly.
care.fertilizing: Very light feeder. Little to no fertilizer needed.
care.pruning: Prune after flowering to shape. Don't cut into old wood.
care.pests: Very few. Root rot if overwatered, powdery mildew.
care.harvesting: Snip sprigs as needed. Best before flowering.
tips: Overwinter indoors in zones 7 and colder
Needs excellent drainage
Can grow into large shrub in mild climates
Woody stems - always leave some green when pruning

planting.notes: Perennial. Replace every 3-4 years as plants get woody.

care.watering: Drought tolerant once established. 1/2 inch per week.
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Too much reduces oil content and flavor.
care.pruning: Cut back by 1/3 in spring to prevent woodiness.
care.pests: Very few. Root rot if overwatered.
care.harvesting: Harvest leaves before flowering. Don't take more than 1/3 at once.
tips: Replace plants every 3-4 years
Great for culinary and medicinal use
Attracts pollinators when flowering
Many ornamental varieties available

planting.notes: Perennial. INVASIVE - plant in containers! Spreads aggressively.

care.watering: Keep consistently moist. 1-2 inches per week.
care.sunlight: Partial shade to full sun (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Moderate feeder. Feed with balanced fertilizer monthly.
care.pruning: Cut back frequently to encourage bushy growth. Remove flowers.
care.pests: Very few. Can get rust disease in humid conditions.
care.harvesting: Harvest before flowering for best flavor. Cut stems above leaf nodes.
tips: ALWAYS plant in containers - very invasive!
Harvest regularly to keep vigorous
Divide plants every 2-3 years
Many varieties - try chocolate mint!

planting.notes: Perennial zones 5-9. Needs excellent drainage. Buy starts.

care.watering: Very drought tolerant. 1/2 inch per week max. Don't overwater!
care.fertilizing: Very light feeder. Too much fertilizer reduces blooms.
care.pruning: Prune after flowering by 1/3. Never cut into old wood.
care.pests: Very few when grown properly. Root rot from overwatering.
care.harvesting: Cut when 50% of flowers are open. Dry upside down.
tips: Must have excellent drainage
Add gravel to planting hole if needed
English lavender most cold-hardy
Don't cut into woody stems - they won't regrow

planting.notes: Self-seeds readily. German chamomile is annual, Roman is perennial.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Tolerates some drought.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Very light feeder. Rich soil reduces flowers.
care.pruning: Harvest flowers regularly to encourage more blooms.
care.pests: Very few. Attracts beneficial insects.
care.harvesting: Pick flowers when fully open. Dry quickly for tea.
tips: German chamomile: annual, best for tea
Roman chamomile: perennial groundcover
Self-seeds readily
Attracts beneficial wasps and hoverflies

planting.notes: Self-seeds readily. Attracts bees. Edible flowers.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Drought tolerant once established.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: No fertilizer needed. Thrives in poor soil.
care.pruning: None needed. Self-seeds prolifically.
care.pests: Very few. Repels tomato hornworms.
care.harvesting: Pick flowers for salads and cocktails. Young leaves edible.
tips: Excellent bee plant - great pollinator attractor
Self-seeds extensively - may need to thin
Blue flowers turn pink in acidic conditions
Cucumber-flavored leaves and flowers

planting.notes: Deters many pests. French marigolds best for companion planting.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Drought tolerant once established.
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Too much fertilizer reduces blooms.
care.pruning: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms.
care.pests: Few pests - they deter many insects! Occasionally spider mites.
care.harvesting: Cut flowers for arrangements. Save seeds from dried flowers.
tips: French marigolds best for pest control
Root secretions deter nematodes
Deadhead regularly for continuous blooms
Excellent trap crop for aphids

planting.notes: Trap crop for aphids. All parts edible. Thrives in poor soil.

care.watering: Moderate water. 1 inch per week. Too much causes leaf growth.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Do NOT fertilize. Poor soil produces more flowers.
care.pruning: None needed. Can trim to shape.
care.pests: Attracts aphids (that's the point - trap crop!).
care.harvesting: Pick leaves, flowers, and seed pods. All edible.
tips: Excellent trap crop - draws aphids away from vegetables
All parts edible with peppery flavor
Don't fertilize - poor soil means more flowers
Trailing varieties great for hanging baskets

planting.notes: Direct sow after frost. Great for pollinators.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week during seed development.
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Side-dress with balanced fertilizer when flowering.
care.pruning: For large single flowers, remove side shoots.
care.pests: Birds love seeds! Use netting if saving seeds.
care.harvesting: Cut when petals fall and back of head is brown. Hang upside down to dry.
tips: Plant tall varieties on north side of garden
Stake tall varieties in windy areas
Succession plant for flowers all summer
Save seeds for birds or next year

planting.notes: Perennial. Plant in early spring. Remove flowers first year.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Critical during fruit development.
care.fertilizing: Feed in spring and after harvest. Use balanced fertilizer.
care.pruning: Remove runners for larger berries. Let some root for new plants.
care.pests: Slugs, birds, and strawberry borer. Use straw mulch and netting.
care.harvesting: Pick when fully red. Harvest every 2-3 days.
tips: Mulch with straw to keep berries clean
Remove runners for bigger berries
Renovate beds every 3-4 years
June-bearing: one big harvest. Everbearing: continuous

planting.notes: Plant dormant bare-root vines in early spring. Takes 2-3 years.

care.watering: Deep watering once per week. 1-2 inches. Established vines are drought tolerant.
care.fertilizing: Feed in spring with balanced fertilizer. Don't over-fertilize.
care.pruning: Essential! Prune 90% of previous year's growth in late winter.
care.pests: Japanese beetles, grape berry moth, birds. Netting helps.
care.harvesting: Taste test for ripeness. Grapes don't ripen after picking.
tips: Pruning is critical - learn proper techniques
Support with strong trellis system
Takes 2-3 years for first real harvest
Different varieties for eating, juice, wine

planting.notes: Plant bare-root trees while dormant. Need 2 trees for pollination.

care.watering: Deep water weekly for young trees. Established trees need less.
care.fertilizing: Feed in early spring. Don't over-fertilize - causes weak growth.
care.pruning: Annual pruning essential. Thin fruit for larger apples.
care.pests: Apple maggot, codling moth, aphids, fire blight. Many issues!
care.harvesting: Apples ready when they twist off easily. Taste test!
tips: Need 2 varieties for pollination
Thin fruit to 6 inches apart for larger apples
Annual pruning critical for production
Choose disease-resistant varieties

planting.notes: Plant in early spring. Needs acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.5).

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Keep consistently moist but not waterlogged.
care.fertilizing: Use acidifying fertilizer for acid-loving plants. Feed in spring.
care.pruning: Remove oldest canes after 6-8 years. Thin crossing branches.
care.pests: Birds! Use netting. Mummy berry disease.
care.harvesting: Wait until berries easily detach. Fully ripe berries are sweeter.
tips: MUST have acidic soil - amend with sulfur if needed
Use peat moss and pine needle mulch
Need 2 varieties for best pollination
Protect from birds with netting

planting.notes: Cool season crop. Harvest when 2-3 inches diameter.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Consistent moisture prevents woody bulbs.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Moderate feeder. Side-dress with nitrogen if growth slows.
care.pruning: None needed. Remove yellowing leaves.
care.pests: Same as cabbage - cabbage worms, aphids, flea beetles.
care.harvesting: Harvest when bulb is 2-3 inches. Gets woody if larger.
tips: Harvest young for tender texture
Both bulb and leaves edible
Purple varieties more cold-hardy
Tastes like mild, sweet broccoli stems

planting.notes: Best as fall crop - flavor improves after frost. Very long season.

care.watering: 1-1.5 inches per week. Consistent moisture important.
care.fertilizing: Heavy nitrogen feeder. Side-dress monthly.
care.pruning: Remove lower leaves as sprouts form. Top plant 3 weeks before harvest.
care.pests: Cabbage worms, aphids, clubroot. Use row covers.
care.harvesting: Pick from bottom up when sprouts are 1-2 inches. Sweetens after frost.
tips: Best flavor after frost
Remove yellowing leaves
Top plant 3 weeks before harvest to speed development
Can harvest through winter with protection

planting.notes: Cut-and-come-again crop. More heat tolerant than spinach.

care.watering: 1 inch per week. Consistent moisture produces tender leaves.
care.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade (4-6 hours)
care.fertilizing: Side-dress with nitrogen every 3-4 weeks.
care.pruning: Harvest outer leaves to encourage new growth.
care.pests: Leaf miners, slugs. Remove affected leaves.
care.harvesting: Cut outer leaves at base when 8-12 inches. Plant keeps producing.
tips: More heat-tolerant than spinach
Cut-and-come-again - keeps producing all season
Rainbow chard is beautiful and edible
Stalks and leaves both usable

planting.notes: Very fast growing. Bolts in heat. Plant every 2 weeks.

care.watering: Keep consistently moist. About 1 inch per week.
care.sunlight: Partial shade in summer (3-4 hours), full sun spring/fall
care.fertilizing: Light feeder. Compost at planting is enough.
care.pruning: Harvest frequently to delay bolting.
care.pests: Flea beetles, aphids. Use row covers.
care.harvesting: Cut leaves at 2-3 inches for baby greens, 6 inches for full size.
tips: Baby leaves are milder
Bolts quickly in heat - grow in spring/fall
Flowers are edible
Self-seeds readily

planting.notes: Best as fall crop - bolts in heat. Plant away from most vegetables.

care.watering: 1-2 inches per week. Consistent moisture for good bulb development.
care.fertilizing: Moderate feeder. Side-dress with compost monthly.
care.pruning: Hill soil around bulb for blanching.
care.pests: Few pests. Aphids occasionally. Attracts swallowtail butterflies.
care.harvesting: Harvest when bulb is 3 inches. Cut at soil level.
tips: Plant away from most vegetables - inhibits their growth
Fall planting best - less bolting
All parts edible - bulb, fronds, seeds
Attracts beneficial insects
